<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/economists-brace-22m-lost-jobs-april?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Worst Report Card in American History
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="unemployment" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84NjcvdXNhLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Every month, the Labor Department releases a comprehensive jobs report. April's numbers <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/unemployment-rate-brace-for-the-single-worst-jobs-report-in-history/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">arrive</a> this morning at 8:30am ET, and expectations haven't been this low since we told our parents we were switching from premed.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With economists predicting ~22 million lost jobs last month, take your pick of superlatives: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The "single worst jobs report in history" (Glassdoor Senior Economist Daniel Zhao)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>"Probably the worst unemployment rate since the Great Depression" (White House Economist Kevin Hassett) </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>"Almost incomprehensibly grim" (Axios)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>"A portrait of devastation" (NYT)</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">First, DTR</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Let’s brush up on <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/jobs-reports-unemployment-gets-counted?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">who and what</a> the government is actually counting here. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Employed: </strong></span><span>People with jobs (full-time, part-time, or temporary)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Unemployed: </strong></span><span>People who are jobless, available to work, </span><span><em>and</em></span><span> actively looked for a role in the last month</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Employed + unemployed </strong></span><span>= the labor force </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The unemployment rate is the percentage of unemployed people in the labor force. Temporarily laid-off workers who expect to return to their job count as unemployed. April's unemployment rate is expected to jump to 16%–20% from 4.4% in March. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Remember, unemployment ≠ “jobless claims.” Yesterday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) said there were <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/05/07/851320519/3-2-million-more-are-out-of-work-as-jobless-claims-keep-piling-up?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">3.2 million jobless claims</a> (applications for unemployment benefits) last week, bringing the two-month total to at least 33.5 million. But not everyone who is unemployed files for benefits. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>During the Great Recession, 7.5 million jobs were lost over 18 months; unemployment peaked around 10%. Great Depression unemployment peaked near 25%. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It's an estimate </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Many experts believe April's numbers, no matter how colossal, could come in below the actual unemployment total. To qualify as "unemployed," someone has to have recently looked for a new job...and many workers feel discouraged by the current economy and aren't bothering. Or are staying home to care for family. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The BLS does offer some </span><span><a href="https://www.bls.gov/charts/employment-situation/alternative-measures-of-labor-underutilization.htm?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">alternative measures</a></span><span> of unemployment, including methods that account for discouraged workers. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>a third-quarter "recovery" could see unemployment drop to 11%, per Moody's. That would still be light years away from February's 3.5%. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For more background on what's in today's report and how to read it, check out our <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/jobs-reports-unemployment-gets-counted?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">guide to labor statistics</a>.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RIDE-HAILING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/uber-lyft-report-headwinds-q1-earnings-reports?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
We Haven’t Hailed Many Rides Recently, Have You?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Uber reported <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/07/uber-uber-earnings-q1-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">disappointing earnings</a> for Q1, but it’s not like we were expecting a blockbuster quarter. On Wednesday, the company announced it would lay off about 14% of its corporate employees to cut costs. Plus, refer back to the headline. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Uber posted its biggest loss in three quarters—$2.9 billion. Analysts were expecting a much smaller loss, but don’t forget about The COVID-19 Caveat(™); estimates are all over the map because of the pandemic. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The number of Uber trips actually rose 7% year-over-year (presumably on strength in Jan. and Feb.). Another positive was Uber’s Eats division, where bookings were up more than 50% annually. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">As for Uber’s pink-mustached doppelgänger </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Same boat with better wind. Lyft also laid off a chunk of its workforce—but on Wednesday reported 23% revenue growth and 3% more active riders than last year. Yesterday, Lyft's stock jumped more than 21%. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>for the month of April, Lyft rides were down about 75% annually; however, the worst seems to be over. Uber saw business <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-results/uber-sees-ride-business-up-from-coronavirus-lows-in-some-u-s-markets-idUSKBN22J39R?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pick up</a> in coronavirus-hit areas last week. </p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ORGANIZED CRIME
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/pandemic-restrictions-slow-global-drug-trade?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Drug Traffickers Have Logistical Problems, Too
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Narcos" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/4TcXJyDk944pdzTELS/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Narcos" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/4TcXJyDk944pdzTELS/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you've ever seen a TV show about the drug trade, you know it resembles a regular industry...with extra murder. It's about getting the right product to the right place at the right time (plus murder). But measures intended to curb the coronavirus pandemic are creating obstacles to that goal, according to a <a href="https://www.unodc.org/unodc/frontpage/2020/May/covid-19-is-changing-the-route-of-illicit-drug-flows--says-unodc-report.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">UN report</a> released yesterday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The details: </strong>Tightened border security and depressed air travel have created logistical challenges to distribution. And a sharp drop in overall global trade poses problems for cocaine traffickers who normally hide their activities behind the cover of legal movement of goods. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, supply issues have complicated production. Labor shortages hamstrung opium harvests in Afghanistan, scarce gasoline availability knocked cocaine output in Colombia, and disruptions to the flow of chemicals from Southeast Asia capped synthetic drug production in Mexico. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The flip side: </strong>The economic devastation caused by the pandemic may force disadvantaged people into the drug trade as a last-resort means of income, the report said.</p>

</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For the sports industry, the coronavirus has proved a black hole so powerful not even the National Spelling Bee could escape. Consider <a href="https://www.espn.com/espn/story/_/id/28871525/coronavirus-cancellations-reactions-sports?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">what we lost</a> in April 2020 alone: the NBA and NHL playoffs, the Boston Marathon, the Masters golf tournament, and much more.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But in the last few days, there have been rumblings of a sports renaissance:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The NFL </strong><a href="http://www.nfl.com/schedules/2020/REG1?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released</a> its 2020 schedule last night; the season is still scheduled to start Sept 10. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">"The Match," part 2: </strong>Tiger Woods and Peyton Manning will battle Phil Mickelson and Tom Brady in a <a href="https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2890625-tiger-phils-the-match-with-manning-brady-date-tv-live-stream-info-more?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">charity golf tournament</a> on May 24. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">NASCAR </strong>is <a href="https://ftw.usatoday.com/2020/05/nascar-schedule-covid-coronavirus-postponed-steve-phelps?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports&stream=top&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">set to return</a> on May 17.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some MLS players </strong>have started <a href="https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2020/05/05/mls-players-returning-training-ground-individual-workouts-starting-wednesday?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports&stream=top&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">training again</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Bundesliga</strong>, Germany's top soccer league, will return May 16. Since no spectators will be allowed, one team is selling <a href="https://www.bundesliga.com/en/bundesliga/news/borussia-monchengladbach-fans-pay-for-cardboard-cut-outs-charity-coronavirus-10911?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cardboard cutouts</a> of fans to place around the stadium. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Just like any other industry, sports will return <em>very slowly</em>. And with strict public health measures in place, it'll look far different than when we left it. </p>

History\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"unemployment\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEvery month, the Labor Department releases a comprehensive jobs report. April's numbers \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/unemployment-rate-brace-for-the-single-worst-jobs-report-in-history/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003earrive\u003c/a\u003e this morning at 8:30am ET, and expectations haven't been this low since we told our parents we were switching from premed.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith economists predicting ~22 million lost jobs last month, take your pick of superlatives: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe \"single worst jobs report in history\" (Glassdoor Senior Economist Daniel Zhao)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"Probably the worst unemployment rate since the Great Depression\" (White House Economist Kevin Hassett) \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"Almost incomprehensibly grim\" (Axios)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"A portrait of devastation\" (NYT)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eFirst, DTR\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLet’s brush up on \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/jobs-reports-unemployment-gets-counted?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewho and what\u003c/a\u003e the government is actually counting here. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eEmployed: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeople with jobs (full-time, part-time, or temporary)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eUnemployed: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeople who are jobless, available to work, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e actively looked for a role in the last month\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eEmployed + unemployed \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e= the labor force \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe unemployment rate is the percentage of unemployed people in the labor force. Temporarily laid-off workers who expect to return to their job count as unemployed. April's unemployment rate is expected to jump to 16%–20% from 4.4% in March. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRemember, unemployment ≠ “jobless claims.” Yesterday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) said there were \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/05/07/851320519/3-2-million-more-are-out-of-work-as-jobless-claims-keep-piling-up?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e3.2 million jobless claims\u003c/a\u003e (applications for unemployment benefits) last week, bringing the two-month total to at least 33.5 million. But not everyone who is unemployed files for benefits. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eDuring the Great Recession, 7.5 million jobs were lost over 18 months; unemployment peaked around 10%. Great Depression unemployment peaked near 25%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt's an estimate \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMany experts believe April's numbers, no matter how colossal, could come in below the actual unemployment total. To qualify as \"unemployed,\" someone has to have recently looked for a new job...and many workers feel discouraged by the current economy and aren't bothering. Or are staying home to care for family. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe BLS does offer some \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bls.gov/charts/employment-situation/alternative-measures-of-labor-underutilization.htm?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ealternative measures\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of unemployment, including methods that account for discouraged workers. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003ea third-quarter \"recovery\" could see unemployment drop to 11%, per Moody's. That would still be light years away from February's 3.5%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor more background on what's in today's report and how to read it, check out our \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/jobs-reports-unemployment-gets-counted?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eguide to labor statistics\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Uber reported \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/07/uber-uber-earnings-q1-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edisappointing earnings\u003c/a\u003e for Q1, but it’s not like we were expecting a blockbuster quarter. On Wednesday, the company announced it would lay off about 14% of its corporate employees to cut costs. Plus, refer back to the headline. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUber posted its biggest loss in three quarters—$2.9 billion. Analysts were expecting a much smaller loss, but don’t forget about The COVID-19 Caveat(™); estimates are all over the map because of the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe number of Uber trips actually rose 7% year-over-year (presumably on strength in Jan. and Feb.). Another positive was Uber’s Eats division, where bookings were up more than 50% annually. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAs for Uber’s pink-mustached doppelgänger \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSame boat with better wind. Lyft also laid off a chunk of its workforce—but on Wednesday reported 23% revenue growth and 3% more active riders than last year. Yesterday, Lyft's stock jumped more than 21%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003efor the month of April, Lyft rides were down about 75% annually; however, the worst seems to be over. Uber saw business \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-results/uber-sees-ride-business-up-from-coronavirus-lows-in-some-u-s-markets-idUSKBN22J39R?utm_source=morning_brew\" width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you've ever seen a TV show about the drug trade, you know it resembles a regular industry...with extra murder. It's about getting the right product to the right place at the right time (plus murder). But measures intended to curb the coronavirus pandemic are creating obstacles to that goal, according to a \u003ca href=\"https://www.unodc.org/unodc/frontpage/2020/May/covid-19-is-changing-the-route-of-illicit-drug-flows--says-unodc-report.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eUN report\u003c/a\u003e released yesterday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe details: \u003c/strong\u003eTightened border security and depressed air travel have created logistical challenges to distribution. And a sharp drop in overall global trade poses problems for cocaine traffickers who normally hide their activities behind the cover of legal movement of goods. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, supply issues have complicated production. Labor shortages hamstrung opium harvests in Afghanistan, scarce gasoline availability knocked cocaine output in Colombia, and disruptions to the flow of chemicals from Southeast Asia capped synthetic drug production in Mexico. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe flip side: \u003c/strong\u003eThe economic devastation caused by the pandemic may force disadvantaged people into the drug trade as a last-resort means of income, the report said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS tournament, and much more.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut in the last few days, there have been rumblings of a sports style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\"The Match,\" part 2: \u003c/strong\u003eTiger Woods and Peyton Manning will battle Phil Mickelson and Tom Brady in a \u003ca href=\"https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2890625-tiger-phils-the-match-with-manning-brady-date-tv-live-stream-info-more?utm_source=morning_brew\" href=\"https://ftw.usatoday.com/2020/05/nascar-schedule-covid-coronavirus-postponed-steve-phelps?utm_source=newsletter\u0026utm_medium=email\u0026utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports\u0026stream=top\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\"
